title: US Workforce AI Exposure
description: Share of US jobs with significant task overlap with current AI capabilities. Exposure measures what AI could automate, not what it has. High exposure does not equal displacement.

overlays.label: PNAS Nexus: AI-exposed occupations face higher unemployment
ILO review: exposure converges on high-wage jobs
OpenAI/UPenn: 80% of workers have ≥10% tasks affected
Cognizant: exposure growing 9%/yr (up from 2%); 30% above 2032 projections
Brookings: Admin support has highest exposure (52.5%) + lowest adaptability

sources.title: The Potentially Large Effects of AI on Economic Growth
sources.excerpt: Roughly two-thirds of current jobs are exposed to some degree of AI automation; generative AI could substitute up to one-fourth of current work.

sources.title: OECD Employment Outlook 2023: AI and the Labour Market
sources.excerpt: 27% of jobs are in occupations at high risk of automation across OECD countries.

sources.title: Gen-AI: Artificial Intelligence and the Future of Work
sources.excerpt: Almost 40% of global employment is exposed to AI, with advanced economies more affected.

sources.title: GPTs are GPTs: An Early Look at the Labor Market Impact Potential of LLMs
sources.excerpt: ~80% of the US workforce could have at least 10% of their tasks affected by GPTs. Legal, accounting, and financial analysis are among the highest-exposure occupations.

sources.title: The Projected Impact of Generative AI on Future Productivity Growth
sources.excerpt: In about 40% of employment in exposed occupations, at least 50% of tasks will be replaceable. Average labor-cost savings ~25% from current tools, potentially 40% as systems improve.

sources.title: The Anthropic Economic Index: Economic Primitives
sources.excerpt: Computer/mathematical tasks account for ~33% of all Claude.ai conversations and ~50% of API traffic, indicating concentrated AI impact on tech-adjacent roles.

sources.title: The Labor Market Effects of Generative Artificial Intelligence
sources.publisher: Stanford / World Bank (Hartley, Jolevski, Melo, Moore)
sources.excerpt: LLM adoption among U.S. workers increased from 30.1% to 38.3% between December 2024 and December 2025. Small effects on wages in exposed occupations; no significant effects on job openings or total jobs.

sources.title: AI exposure predicts unemployment risk
sources.excerpt: Workers in AI-exposed occupations face significantly higher unemployment risk.

sources.title: AI and jobs: A review of theory, estimates, and evidence
sources.excerpt: Productivity gains 20-60% in controlled RCTs, 15-30% in field experiments; AI exposure measures converge toward high-wage jobs being most exposed.

sources.title: New Work, New World 2026: How AI is Reshaping Work
sources.excerpt: Education task exposure jumped from 11% to 49% — a 4.5x increase driven by multimodal AI, advanced reasoning, and agentic systems. Based on reassessment of 18,000 tasks across 1,000 O*NET occupations.

sources.title: Measuring US workers' capacity to adapt to AI-driven job displacement
sources.excerpt: Administrative support occupations have lower adaptive capacity (0.360) combined with the highest AI exposure of any major occupation group (0.525).
